Essex County Asset Builder Network
July 2 at 2:33 PM ·

Calling all Teens!
Are you interested in making a difference in your community? Has the epidemic left you at home with no summer job or camps? Are you looking for a creative outlet or a way to get involved in activism in your community? Join us for Make/Do 2020!
Any young person ages 13-24 can submit a project they would like to do that would help better our community. It can be anything from art, to volunteering to working with a local organization. The sky is the limit! Funds are available to help support these projects. Proposals due by July 15th and will need to be completed by August 31. Even if you don’t have an idea fully thought through or you don’t know what you want to do but you know you want to do something meaningful let us know! We will have our team work with you to make your idea viable or connect you with an opportunity. Visit www.ECABNetwork.org to submit a project and learn more!

Good Afternoon,

As we navigate through the challenges that this current closure presents, there are many factors contributing to what student learning can and should look like. As a public education institution, our charge is to provide a Free and Appropriate Education (FAPE) for all students. With the schools closed, the only opportunity for learning is the ‘distance’ model. While access to technology and the internet is an obvious challenge in a distance learning model, the range of academic abilities and disabilities presents the most difficult obstacles to overcome.

To that end, we have established expectations for enrichment opportunities that will keep our students engaged and supported by their teachers and other educators. We have posted what parents can expect in regards to academic support from Triton educators during the closure on our website at https://www.tritonschools.org/#tab-id-2.

As always, if there are any questions, please don't hesitate to reach out to me directly at Brian.Forget@tritonschools.org.

Regards,
Brian

Over the last several days, our students district wide have been busy working on serving others through a variety of projects to honor #MLKday National Day of Service and our Triton Year of Giving campaign.

Our projects included:
- Students from the elementary schools, middle school and high school decorated tote bags with inspirational MLK Jr. quotes which were filled with toiletries collected at SES, books from PGS, and birthday party supplies collected from TMS. We would like to thank our partners in this project Youth Service America, Mott Foundation, Corporation for National and Community Service and Salem Five for making this day possible! Go Triton!

post_text: We would like to thank our community speakers for their recent STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics) presentations! In October, third graders at Salisbury Elementary were treated to programs from Dr. Steve Perrin, a research scientist from the ALS Therapy Development Institute who taught the kids all about DNA, and Ashley Stokes, Marine Rescue Manager from the Seacoast Science Center. Yesterday at Pine Grove Elementary, 5th grade students were enthralled and engaged hearing from inventor and business owner, Bill Danner with his hands on presentation of simple machines, engineering and everyday applications. We were also thrilled to have Ashley Stokes join us at PGS with her incredible marine rescue presentation bringing science, chemistry, math and a love for animals to life in a career! Thank you presenters for engaging our students to "See Themselves in STEM" and creating that spark for lifelong learning!

UPDATE: ALL SCHOOLS CLOSED!!! Unfortunately the earlier estimates provided for power restoration for the major outage in Byfield and other small outages and downed lines/trees across our towns are not panning out as continued winds are delaying repairs. The latest estimates from National Grid are that power will not be restored until later this afternoon or evening to all areas.

For that reason, all Triton Schools will be CLOSED today, Thursday, October 17th. This is a change from the original 2 hour delay communicated earlier. We were doing our best to open schools to avoid a weather related closure so early in the season, as well as giving as much time this morning as possible for power to be restored. However, we cannot delay any longer and also provide families enough time to plan for this change, so I am making the call to change to a closure at this time.

Here's to hoping this winter does NOT continue on this stormy pattern! 😔

A slightly different kind of post....🙂 I spoke to all faculty and staff at our first day back earlier this week about taking healthy risks and getting outside our comfort zones. I figured I needed to walk the talk....I am not a fan of heights (understatement) so with my family in tow, side by side, we ventured to the zip line tour at Wildcat Mountain. As is often the case when you take a risk, I had SO much fun, and can't wait to go back and do it again! Make a commitment to take a healthy risk and try something new this year...you'll be glad you did!

Here's the video to prove it.....Heidi (my wife) sends her apologies for all the screaming! 😁 🤣
